findings.title: Semver is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS)
findings.description: The Semver library is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack.

findings.title: L02. Improper Input Validation at Views/Routes
findings.description: Input validation is a frequently used technique for safeguarding against potentially harmful inputs, ensuring that they are safe for processing within the code or when interacting with other components.

findings.title: H01. Use of own crypto
findings.description: The application utilizes its custom encryption implementation for data security and integrity verification.

findings.title: H02. Hardcoded TRON Pro API Key
findings.description: The application relies on a hardcoded Tron API key which can lead to DoS attacks by exhausting the daily quota for the Tron API key.

findings.title: H03. Vendor-Disapproved Usage of Tron’s “Sign” Function
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: M01. Too Wide Manifest Permissions
findings.description: The application manifest supports extension loading on all pages and filesystem files, particularly content_scripts and the framing of the scripts, allowing unsafe HTTP (unencrypted) to load the extension and enabling attackers to compromise it with a high probability.

findings.title: M02. Mnemonic in Memory Immediately After Unlocking
findings.description: The mnemonic is stored in clear text memory immediately after unlocking the application, exposing a risk of account compromise by an attacker with computer access.

findings.title: M03. Insufficient Origin Check for Tab-originated Messages
findings.description: The absence of origin checking creates a broad attack surface, allowing an attacker to manipulate transaction parameters and steal user assets.

findings.title: L01. Vulnerable Dependencies
findings.description: The dependency analyzer tools have identified several weaknesses, with the most severe ones being Semver vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS).

findings.title: The Use of Weak RC4 and AES-CTR Crypto Algorithms
findings.description: The application currently utilizes weak crypto algorithms, specifically RC4 and AES-CTR, in the `packages/utils/src/encrypt.ts` file.

findings.title: L04. Sensitive Data Exposure through Clipboard
findings.description: The application's current feature allowing users to copy both the seed phrase and the password to the clipboard poses a significant security risk.

findings.title: L05. Connection Allowed Under a Locked Wallet
findings.description: The application allows the wallet to be connected even when it is in a locked state, potentially allowing an attacker to view the user's account.

findings.title: L06. UnlimitedStorage Permission in the Extension Manifest
findings.description: The 'unlimitedStorage' permission exempts extensions from standard quota restrictions and eviction, potentially leading to a denial of service on the user's computer.

findings.title: L07. Excessive `tabs` permission in the manifest
findings.description: The extension employs the 'tabs' permission in its manifest which grants access to privileged fields of the Tab objects used by various APIs, including Chrome's tabs and chrome.windows, but it's not necessary to declare this permission to utilize those APIs.

findings.title: L08. Blacklist of Phishing Domains Not In Use
findings.description: The application lacks an implementation of a blacklist for phishing Dapps, which increases users' awareness and provides warnings about potential issues with Dapps.

findings.title: I01. Statically Hardcoded Package
findings.description: The extension relies heavily on the webext-bridge library and maintains a separate branch of packages, which can increase the risk that critical operational or security issues may not be promptly addressed and fixed.

findings.title: I02. Sentry Reporting May Violate User Privacy
findings.description: The hacken team could not find this privacy policy. Customer promised that they will amend it to explicitly mention Sentry and other similar tools.

findings.title: I03. Wasm Unsafe Eval In The Manifest
findings.description: The application includes 'wasm-unsafe-eval' in its Content Security Policy (CSP) within the manifest, allowing the execution of WebAssembly (wasm) bytecode.

findings.title: I06. Unfixed Dependency Version
findings.description: The application package.json files do not specify fixed dependency versions in some instances, which could introduce potential risks where future updates could inadvertently break the security or other essential properties of the software.

findings.title: I08. Incomplete Test Coverage of Cryptography Code
findings.description: The application's code lacks full test coverage for its cryptography-related components.

findings.title: I09. Reliance on Unaudited hw ledger Library
findings.description: The application's code relies on the 'https://github.com/Zondax/ledger-substrate-js' library, which lacks readily identifiable audit reports and includes an unaudited 'hd_key_derivation' function.

findings.title: I10. Support for Outdated Browsers
findings.description: The application manifest file indicates support for relatively old browsers, such as Chrome 67 from 2018.

findings.title: I10. Lack of Exception Handling in Signature Verification
findings.description: The application fails to check for exceptional situations when using the `ethereumjs-util.ecrecover` routine for signature verification.

findings.title: I11. Requests to Subdomains of the Main RPC
findings.description: The application makes attempts to contact all subdomains of the custom network’s RPC endpoint, which could allow an attacker to set his own domain and impersonate a node of the user.

findings.title: I12. Use of Hard-coded Credentials at Ethereum Libs and Bitcoin tests
findings.description: The product contains hard-coded credentials, including passwords and cryptographic keys, which are utilized for its inbound authentication, outbound communication with external components, or encryption of internal data.
